entry.title: Team friction
entry.body: My cofounder and I keep having the same argument about priorities. She wants to focus on sales, I want to focus on product. We had this discussion three times this month.

outputs.editor:
SUMMARY:
You and your cofounder repeatedly argue about whether to focus on sales or product.
FIXES:
- "keep having the same argument": specify what decisions are blocked.
- "priorities": define the concrete trade-off.
- "three times this month": note when these discussions happened.
REWRITE:
My cofounder and I keep arguing about whether to prioritize sales or product, and it's happened three times this month.
outputs.definer:
KEY TERMS:
- "priorities": which activities get time and budget first.
- "focus on sales": spending time on outreach and closing deals.
AMBIGUITIES:
- "keep having": could mean weekly or just a few times.
- "focus on product": could mean building features or fixing quality issues.
BOUNDARIES:
- Not claiming: either strategy is wrong.
- Not claiming: the conflict is personal.
outputs.skeptic:
CORE CLAIM:
There is a fundamental disagreement about whether sales or product should come first.
CHALLENGES:
- "keep having the same argument": it's natural for cofounders to have ongoing discussions about strategy. This could simply be healthy debate.
- "three times this month": having regular discussions shows you're both engaged. That's a positive sign.
- "focus on product": product focus has merits, especially for building something users want.
TEST:
Try alternating weeks: one week on sales priorities, one week on product priorities.
outputs.coach:
INTENT:
You want alignment on priorities ("same argument about priorities").
OPTIONS:
- Run a one-week sales sprint, risking delayed product work. Done looks like a shared list of leads contacted.
- Run a one-week product sprint, risking fewer sales conversations. Done looks like a shipped product change.
- Define a split schedule (3 days sales, 2 days product), risking slower progress in each. Done looks like a written schedule.
RECOMMENDATION:
Pick a one-week sales sprint because it creates a clear experiment and reduces debate. It closes the option of re-litigating priorities for 7 days.
FOR THE NEXT 7 DAYS, STOP:
- Reopening the priority debate
- Adding new priority categories
